posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

I always tell people that it's not a game for everyone, it only got hyped due to smash etc.

I had the similar history with this game.

I tried to play it for the first time some 15-18 years ago and I didn't get it, I barely made it past the intro. I tried again some 5 years later and went further along the game but quickly got bored, again.

It's only in the recent years that I enjoyed it. I fell in like with Dragon Quest, following that I played Earthbound Beginnings which I adored. After beating that, I finally playthrough through Earthbound and enjoyed it, but coming from the first game it's a huge disappointment.
There are many things in the second game that are there "just so it is like the first game", such as the whole melody thing, except it doesn't fit in Earthbound and doesn't have an explanation. The first game also had more freedom, more exploration, and more importantly, more challenge, which is why Earthbound was still a disappointment.
However, the first game lacked in dungeons and in actual bosses (starting half way through the game, you're given a freebie against every boss, and they're not numerous to begin with). In comparison the second game shined in that regard: many and varied dungeons, many bosses.

Maybe it's because I didn't wait so long to play this game (though I still played it rather late in relation to when it was released). Although I'm not the kind of person to let others influence what I should like or not, positively or negatively, but I should mention I'm not the biggest RPG fan or non-action games in general (though I did enjoy some classic ones like Dragon Quest III).
I don't know what people like OP expect from this game, but I was pleased with Earthbound: seeing enemies on the map and even being able to sneak behind them/instakill weaker enemies was a pretty welcome change from most other RPGs, that alone made me enjoy it more than most.
The HP rolling mechanic made the turn based menu combat somewhat a bit more dynamic than in other games, too.
The limited inventory was, I think, clever on the dev's parts as it encourages actually spending items instead of hoarding like a scrub.
I actually played this game because of Keiichi Suzuki's music, as I love his band Moonriders and his other many music projects, he's a legend. And Shigesato Itoi's writing is also a nice condiment.
I was also drawn in by the simple, colorful art direction, it's very quintessential 16-bit.
Again not sure what people like OP expect, but I thought it was above average for sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What EB did good:
>enemy encounters visible on the map instead of random encounters means you can actually tell if you need to heal before you reach an exit or not
>also allows you to see new enemies in areas before you fight them
>rolling HP counters allow for recovery from fatal attacks if you can get some healing in fast enough, adding a rare sense of urgency to turn-based combat
>sister's storage system is a direct upgrade from normal item bank systems, since it can be accessed anywhere you can find a phone
>phones acting as save points and item storage access points means you have frequent access to both, including inside of dungeons
>L-button acting as a 2nd A button allows you to play mostly one-handed for easy grinding or walking around and talking to NPCs
>auto-win mechanic speeds up grinding since you don't have to fight weak enemies at all
>built-in optional hint system for new players to prevent them from getting stuck
What EB did bad:
>condiment system might as well not exist, better to have a full load of healing items instead of half a load of slightly buffed healing items
>prayer might as well not exist, since Paula's attack magic is far more reliable and less dangerous to the party
>pizza delivery serves no point, since you can buy better healing items without having to wait
>homesickness mechanic is pure tedium and only serves to slow the game down
>combat direction encounter system is rarely used as on paper, instead it's mostly grey head-on encounters, the rare red when caught while trying to run away, and the green against weaker enemies that run away and you corner
>last half of the game has a lot of backtracking, and the final area is just a level check with a healing/save point so you can grind until you can pass it
>mushroom status has annoying interface screw effect on map which just slows things down
>bicycle is completely worthless the moment you get Paula until you drop her off at home at the end of the game

>>9569786
Earthbound's translation is famous for being one of the best and most faithful ones out there considering how hard it would normally be to translate a game like this barring legal changes(Red Cross being removed, Coca Cola trucks being changed, Grateful Dead Valley being changed Peaceful Rest Valley, Naked Ness being censored, Monopoly tournmanent being changed to Strip Poker etc.) and some stupid shit the translator changed such as Paula's line about how she "would have started crying" if Ness didn't show up to save her because the translator was a soiboy feiminist(this inadvertently ruins the RPG satire about how LV1 Paula is weak and powers up throughout the game).

But overall it's a fantastic localization and recently somebody did a hack called "Mother 2 Perfect Edition" which for the most part keeps his script and just fixes the shit that needed fixing and it shows how well the original translation holds up.
Only thing I have against Perfect Edition is that they still kept the name "Giygas" and didn't change it to the proper "Gyiyg". This stupid fanboy shit really annoys me because I've seen many people who think that Gyiyg(or Giegue) from Mother 1 and Giygas are two different entities when they are clearly the same villain and Itoi literally even makes it clear in a 1992 preview for Mother 2 saying that "Gyiyg attacked them again".
People still get confused to this day due to the names being different in the translations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9569786
>Nintendo of America's Dan Owsen began the English localization project and converted about ten percent of the script before moving to another project.[14] Marcus Lindblom filled Owsen's position around January 1995.[34] Lindblom credits Owsen with coining some of the game's "most iconic phrases", such as "say fuzzy pickles".[14] Lindblom himself was given liberties to make the script "as weird as [he] wanted", as Nintendo wanted the script to be more American than a direct translation would be.[34] He worked alone and with great latitude due to no divisional hierarchies.[17][nb 10] Lindblom was aided by Japanese writer Masayuki Miura, who translated the Japanese script and contextualized its tone,[14] which Lindblom positively described as "a glass half full".[34]

Lindblom was challenged by the task of culturally translating "an outsider's view of the U.S." for an American audience.[34] He also sought to stay true to the original text, though he never met or spoke with Itoi.[34] In addition to reworking the original puns and humor, Lindblom added private jokes and American cultural allusions to Bugs Bunny, comedian Benny Hill, and This Is Spinal Tap.[34] Apart from the dialogue, he wrote the rest of the game's text, including combat, prompts and item names.[14] As one of several Easter eggs, he named a non-player character for his daughter, Nico, who was born during development. While Lindblom took the day off for her birth,[34] he proceeded to work 14-hour days[14] without weekends for the next month.[34]

>>9569858
>there's not even half as many interesting characters there as in the first half of the game, the atmosphere feels half-assed
It'd be boring if the whole game was the same but realistically there was only so much space in the cartridge and Earthbound was already upgraded twice since it first started development as an 8Mbit game then got upgraded to 16megs and then finally 24.

And I don't see why you're complaining so much about Scaraba, Dalaam and the Prehistoric World since none of them last that long. Scaraba doesn't last that long + it winds up connecting to Summers in the story AND it also has Dungeon Man/Brickroad going for it.
And the Deep Darkness Jungle is obviously meant to be a contrast to the rest of the location and is where you find Monotoli's helicopter.

I think most can agree that the first half of the game is better but the second half is by no mean bad and while the middle portions of the game are weaker the game does end in a strong note.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9569894
I knew the argument would be "but they made the world bigger". With what, gimmicky half-assed locations that break the setting? Oh I know, it's not "just" Egypt, it's le quirky Egypt. OK. What does it have to do with modern day America? This breaks the whole "everyday life / modernity / aliens" setting of EB.
More importantly, this is far closer to cliche locations in video games. Yeah, give us more sewers with bats, ice world, lava world, etc. Because that's why people play Earthbound, to play a generic RPG with half-assed mechanics.
>And I don't see why you're complaining so much about Scaraba, Dalaam and the Prehistoric World since none of them last that long.
Just because they're short doesn't mean they are good. And jumping locations every time breaks any sense of continuity.
I simply believe that something needs to tie things together. Winters is at least tied into plot because Jeff lives there, there's a cast of characters there that make you feel some sort of connection to the place.
In a perfect world, I'd make Summers a part of Eagleland, and you go there either by bus or by plane to keep with the "modern life" theme. Expand it and make it into a parody of 80s Miami or Cali, with pastel suits, cops, etc. I'd take 1 actually well-written location vs 5 half-assed ones.
Then instead of going on world tour, how about going somewhere else in America? Again, just as an example, a parody of famous places like Hollywood, Las Vegas, and so on. Tie old characters into it, like Blues Bros landing a movie deal, then blowing all their cash in casinos. And finally going back to your small home town to contrast it with the "big world".
That's how you get a far more cohesive atmosphere that makes sense. Mother 1 managed to reach peak cohesion, as everything was part of 1 big map. That said, it didn't focus on plot or atmosphere that much, but regardless, the cohesion is 10/10 for a NES RPG.

posts.com: TP is the one Zelda game they were sort of reluctant to make and was basically created as a reaction to TWW's relatively lackluster sales. You can also tell from the way the story progresses that there was a point where they wanted to take it in a different direction and give the game some much-needed identity of its own, before pivoting into just rehashing OoT some more, for better or worse. Yes, the original bits (the wolf segments) were among the most boring and they were right to largely pivot away from them past the midpoint of the game, but there were a lot of cool things they could've done with the regular human Link segments that end up feeling like wasted potential. And let's not even get into how the story outright shits the bed past Midna's Desperate Hour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Almost one week with the RG351v (ARKos). Thoughts so far:

- Battery reading is pretty inaccurate. Sometimes you turn it off, turn it on and the next time the percentage is a 1% higher

- Battery + built in wifi = bad: If you are going to download thumbnails / boxart or update cores / assets, do it while connected to the DC and disable wifi immediately after. It sucked a 30% just doing that.

- Gaming experience: Surprised to see it can do CPS3 with not a lot of hiccups. GBA paired with the LCD3X shader mitigates well enough the scaling artifacts when not using integer scaling. 240p PSX games like Klonoa are the ones that benefit the most from the small screen. Snes and Nes are as annoying as ever with the non square pixels if you have bad OCPD about stretching artifacts, as usual.

- Comfort: The d-pad is placed higher than on the og gameboy, so the corner gets into the soft of the hand and hurts a bit until you learn to adapt the posture. The analog stick placement justifies why I did not want the model with two of them. For Ridge Racer Type 4 I just place the left hand lower to not feel it too much. If I really wanted to play an analog only game, I would end using the Gamesir X2 instead.

- Commuting and travelling: Beats lugging around a Nintendo Switch for a quickie in the train. Easier to store. Loses points for not having bluetooth. I can do without wifi, but headphone cables are always a risk

- Did I really need this: Sure, it's cool to be able to play MVS Meta Slug X on the go, but then I ask myself why would I want to play on a "tiny screen" when I can do it on a 40" tv and see all the details. It's great as a replacement for aging handheld consoles, but for TV out consoles it may be better to get one of the other handhelds with bigger screens

That's it for now, I guess. Decent hardware, Need to find a pouch for it. the grey color, rather than the old GB, reminds me more of the Watara Supervisision.

>>9544585
>random knock off device
No. It’s the gp2x the successor to the gp32 the first handheld emulation machine ever made, shit for brains. Both of these consoles were huge in the home brew scene and sparked the handheld emulation scene we have today. I’m dead serious. Gamepark split up after making the gp32, which caused the gp2x to be made, but the teams were competing with each other which eventually led to the pyra and the gpd win to be the competitors. That was the beginning of the hand held computer and handheld emulation machine fad that we see now. It all stems from the massive home brew scene on the gp32 and gp2x. It doesn’t get you very far being a dumb faggot, but now you know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9567815
>>9567832
This is what you should do on Retroarch for optimal latency on any platform:

- Disable threaded video
- Enable Hard GPU Sync, set to 1
- Runahead set to 1, second instance
- Input Poling to Early or Late, this varies depending on the device so set which feels better to you
- You can also use Frame Delay to shave a few extra ms, but it causes hiccups so I don't like using it.

This usually knocks the input lag from a standard ~5 frames to 3 or even less depending on the device which is pretty good.

If you're on Android, Bluetooth controllers will ad about 1 or 2 frames of lag, so I'd recommend a Type-C controller

Also, the reason why you don't see people complaining on weak devices is that most people are casuals and have never experienced low input lag in their lives, so they literally just play on threaded video and don't care

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9568807
For got to mention but you also want to set Audio delay to as low as possible without it crackling, Retroach comes with 128ms of audio delay by default and it's fucking terrible. 48ms is a pretty safe bet for most devices and low enough that you can't notice any audio delay

>>9569323
I'll try my best to explain what the fuck is really going on here.

One year before Metroid's release in 1985 the Dirty Pair television series aired on Japanese TV. During this time period science fiction in general was experiencing a boom on account of Return of the Jedi releasing just a few years prior.

Samus's helmet and her profession, intergalactic bounty hunter, were clearly inspired by Boba Fett. (Just one of the many references, like Ridley being named after the director of Aliens.)

As for her unarmored form, it was inspired by Yuri from Dirty Pair, a series whose popularity at the time could not be overstated. Dirty Pair was everywhere during that time period and had many copycats and references. In fact, Time Gal, lifts the design wholesale.

But Samus's unarmored form was only really supposed to be an easter egg for players skilled enough to complete the game in time. There wasn't much more thought to it beyond that and its design was based on the most popular female design of the time period.

Most people weren't even aware that Samus was female until the late 90s. They just assumed the person you played as was a guy.

I think it's because a lot of kids born in the 80s like me, pre-internet, didn't think of the concept of furries. To us animal people was mainly seen as that thing Disney did so we associated it with that. That's not to say it didn't create a ton of furries, it totally did, but most people it didn't and the idea that people would get off to pic related was an unknown concept to us prior to the internet revealing it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9569198
It does use 8x16 sprite mode, I don't know a single Konami game which doesn't (perhaps early ones?), and that is precisely why it flickers more.

Imagine that other sprites are on the same X axis as the first 8x8 pixels of the sprite. In 8x8 sprite mode, only that 8x8 sprite will ficker, but in 8x16 mode, the entire 8x16 sprite will flicker, thus effectively flickering an area twice as big for the same situation.
8x16 mode has other pros, but its con is that it leads to flickering bigger sprites.

>>9569334
I once asked a Japanese poster what they thought of these games, and the answer was he wasn't even aware there were Japanese made games not released in Japan.
I wasn't surprised.
I suppose there are hardcore Famicom fans who do play NES games, just like we do the contrary, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I had a similar question a year or two back, didn't get any answers. My cheap chink adapter (black, 2 ports), like most of these, has a big problem with deadzones. The PS joysticks have always been shit, so they need deadzones, but the problem is that not every PS controller uses those shit jittery sticks. My NeGcon had a massive deadzone, we're talking like 3-4mm because the chinks just built in the deadzone instead of doing proper controller detection or letting the end user configure it.

I think the best option is honestly just buying one of these to use as a female adapter and then solder it to an arduino. That's what I did for Saturn. I don't really use my NeGcon anymore so I haven't bothered building a PS1 version, the cheap adapter works fine with digital controllers like the OG one and Densha De Go, where all the PC games have been modded to support all the console peripherals.

>Not sure what your priorities are, though

Mostly challenging "footsies". My favorite thing in Castlevania tends to be nailing those high commitment whips and jumps against relatively dynamic and unpredictable baddies.

Second most important being just good platforming making use of those tense high commitment jumps.

Castlevania 4 is generally just a bit too easy. Feels like the stages weren't really designed around the 8 way whipping and changeable jump arcs, since there's so many times where you can easily whip enemies from the floor below or before they can even attack you, and the platforming rarely puts too much pressure on you.

Hell I remember picking it up for the first time in ten years (with almost no memory of any of the stage layouts and bosses) and making it up to the final boss rush without a game over. That's kind of how pushover the game is. Combine that with how loooooooong it is and it can start to feel kind of monotonous in a single sitting playthrough despite how nice the art and music is.

I don't hate it but I like it mostly for the atmosphere and nostalgia. I think I'd put it below 1, 3 ,Bloodlines, x68, and Rondo in terms of level design and mechanics.

>>9553141
>You said Hagane

I've 1cc'd a lot of shmups and old games over time. I only really recorded or uploaded the ones I considered particularly challenging. Hagane I thought was an easier clear and took me very little time to do, so I didn't bother recording it.

I don't know why you think that one is a crown jewel of difficulty, I've never heard anyone hold that up on retro forums as particularly challenging. I guess the second loop where everything has super extra HP is harder

>No it's not and 99% of people agree, which is why games evolved the way they did

Even if it were true that consensus means better, that's really not true. There are tons of enduring franchises (including modern, still running ones) that are built around strategic limitations.

Dark Souls for example is pretty much just OG Classicvania combat in 3d. You have non-cancellable attack animations that are not instant and can't be moved during, mobility options which are very limited and set your trajectory in stone for a very specific location, etc.

Or then there's the enduring popularity of many horror games and action-horror games built around strategically limited controls. Resident Evil 2 Remake may have done away with tank controls, but it still put harsh limitations on players movement and dodging options and it was applauded for it. The same could be said of Dead Space 1 and 2 which are absurdly popular and are more or less based on the same very rigid control limitations of RE4-5 and Remake 2, just applied to a more high adrenaline action game.

Making it so you can move and attack at the same time or change the trajectory of mobility moves isn't better or worse (or even more popular are less). It's a design decision that enforces different styles of play.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9553073
>cant kill Shaft
Grab the Bible from the breakable wall before the boss rush, it makes every boss easier but especially Shaft because you can use it to knock away his fireballs. For the lightning orbs, admittedly that's kind of a crapshoot but if they start drifting away from each other you want to be between them, towards each other you need to backflip away from both of them ASAP. For his third attack, try to backflip over the orbs when they come towards you. It's tough but doable.

As for Dracula phase 1, grab the cross at the start of the level. Whenever Dracula shows up, toss a cross at his face and then backflip over his fireballs. It might take some time to get a good feel for how far from him you have to be, but once you get the timing down he's completely toothless. Also, he'll do the magma ball attack on his 4th teleport first, then on every 5th teleport after that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9567996
This is a pretty stupid comparison because shmups and Beat em Ups are about attrition and the "continue" spam is only a thing because they drop you back in right where you stopped. A platformer like Castlevania restarts you at a previous checkpoint. So you can't tank your way through a segment by spamming continues since you still have to do segments you didn't beat on your own merit all over. All the continues do is eliminate the repetition of having to re-do levels you've already beat. You're just talking about an arbitrary challenge run at this point.

nope
platformers like ghosts n goblins also have checkpoint system, yet the difficulty of the games (and the player skill required) is reduced astronomically when you compare a legit 1CC run vs a continue spammed run.
Although you get sent back to a checkpoint you regain full armor again and can tank a couple hits, meanwhile in Castlevania games you typically can tank many more hits via the lifebar. And simply being able to re-try jumps and fights is in itself a tremendous difficulty reducer and skill reducer, nevermind being able to tank extra hits to make it to the next checkpoint

>>9561852
>>9562098
BF1942 was big fun when it was released and there was a wide range of skill levels present on every server. It turned into a janky mess once most people moved on to Battlefield 2 or Battlefield Vietnam. All the players left behind figured out the most efficient way to play was to either bomb people from so far up they can't be hit by AA fire, to nail people with tank fire like an artillery cannon, or to dump grenades near them. Since then, every map with planes will be the players who reached the aircraft first dominating everyone on the ground, all maps with tanks are determined by which side has more tank spawns, and maps without vehicles or jeep-only are grenade and explosive pack battles. If you find that fun, the game is still playable, otherwise it's been dead for a really long time.
I played the shit out of the game when it first came out, and I've played it a bit off and on the last couple of years. I get more enjoyment out of playing singleplayer with the bots than I do playing online with the sweaty try-hards all using the same maximum efficiency play-style that are the only people left playing anymore. If I can't have fun and get involved in crazy battles and jeep races, then I might as well just play against the AI. The AI is far from a great experience, and certainly nowhere near as dynamic as the servers used to be, but at least it doesn't insta-kill you from outside of your visible range. Certainly have never had the AI spawn-kill half the allied team on Omaha Beach with the cannons and then sink the ship almost immediately after the round started.

Astonish game. Defined my youth alone with Doom and Quake. I played a lot of Quake deathmatch, even in a "clan" back when those were a thing, but Tribes was what really instilled that sense of camaraderie and team spirit. God I love that game. I'd always run atypical loadouts; for me it was the plasma gun. EVERYONE went spinfusor. It was a great weapon, sure. But it meant people only practiced to be good against other disc users. They weren't as well prepared for the alternate firing patterns and projectile mechanics of those hot orange plasma balls. ELF gun, too. Loved playing the saboteur. Even funny for snatching people out of the air, lol.

The maps in this game, considering most are just basic terrain heightmaps with a few prefab buildings plopped down. Snowblind.. Skara Brae.. Siege.. and of course Raindance. Desert of Death was a fun twist too, really took advantage of the otherwise underutilized indoor content.

What was your first experience playing Doom?
>late 1994 sunday afternoon
>7yr old me, obsessed with Mortal Kombat 2
>don't read gaming magazines, out of the loop about PC games in general
>dad brings home a big box with cool artwork and floppies inside
>"drop your nintendo, anon, I've got something here"
>"nooo dad, not your simulators again"
>(I actually loved playing F117 with him but all I wanted to play at the moment was Mortal Kombat 2)
>"It's a shooter game like contra but it's in first person like you are watching the action with your own eyes, anon"
>"yeah dad, like in your simulators. This is a really stupid idea"
>dad switches on the PC. I don't like it much because "Super Nintendo has cooler games" and I'm always afraid to break it somehow. I am not allowed to switch it on and use it on my own
>Windows 3.1 starts but dad shuts it down to "free the memory"
>starts a blue-windowed shell instead
>I am looking at the game box while the game installs. It says Doom II
>some of my classmates were joking about Doom when the lights went flickering in the class. Never seen the game myself and never knew that there are two of them
>after the setup process the game is launched, first level starts, I see pic related
>"huh, these stairs look cool"
>dad moves around, shoots
>"definitely cool"
>I ask to try myself and for the rest of the session it's just me playing and dad watching me play and giving advice
>we finish the game a couple of weeks later. Keyboard only, frequently getting scared and lost in the levels, save scumming
>It's the best gaming experience in my life, thanks dad.

Fucking horrible game even for 1993 standards. Cannon Fodder and Syndicate left it in the dust that very same year. Doom was an absolute snoozefest that became boring within a week once the novelty wore off. It had a really huge mass appeal because anyone with more than half a braincell could get into it. I stuck with Wolfenstein 3D for the performance reasons, but still managed to play though on those low settings. Unlike how it seems to be played by all others, perhaps I did not like it as much since I took it more cautiously trying not to waste the resources on the ground (small health at 10 damage, large for 25, and I would save the items that boost over 100% to collect in backtracking after everything was dead). I guess this was the reason I am not as impressed with the genre like others, but that's my odd taste in games yet I still think it is a very good game.

>>9560493
For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993 and have about half left over (people didn't do this at the time). Doom only needed a 486 to run well, which hovered at around $1000 at the time, and would keep dropping. By the time Doom 2 was in stores, a 486 computer with a mouse and the memory to use it together with the game would be WELL under the $1000 mark. Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two, with the original game's first episode being widely available dirt cheap, or even for free. Most people probably experienced it this way, many using the 386 or even 486 at their school, university, or workplace.
That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.

To conclude, your dad should have pulled out, because clearly he couldn't afford to raise you if the prospect of playing Doom was prohibitively expensive. You must have grown up somewhere incredibly poor and undeveloped.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561281
>For $5000 you could get a brand new Pentium computer around 1993
You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
>Doom only needed a 486 to run well
With basic ass 486DX-33, you needed to set the quality to minimum and reduce the window size by 25% or less to get a comfortable framerate.
>which hovered at around $1000 at the time
More like $2000 for the basic ass 486DX-33. Even a shitty 386DX would be well over $1000. A bare minimum spec PC with 486DX2 66MHz, the minimum CPU for running Doom comfortably, would run you up for almost $2500. 486SX was choppy as hell and with 486DX you needed to scale down the screen size by something like 25% and set the quality down to minimum, but it will still get choppy when the game throws more enemies at you. Not sure if using more RAM than the minimum spec of 4MB will help the game run better, I suppose it does at higher quality and resolution.
>Not to talk about the older and much cheaper 386 machines which would run the game well enough in low detail mode and the screen size cut down a step or two
More like in half or less.
>That's in addition to said PC, even on the lower end, being capable of playing MANY other good games, as well as all kinds of office, work, and utility software.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561337
>You'll need that if you want full and consistent framerate.
If you wanted the full 35fps at all times, sure, but the vast majority of people hadn't ever experienced that with a game of that graphical fidelity (compare to Ultima Underworld). The game being able to stay consistently above 20fps was already incredibly fluid for most people at the time. Compare.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=foHUXGzHOx0

Never mind that you definitely did not have to spend up to $2500. You didn't have to buy a complete pre-built, you could build your own, even reuse components from an older computer (such as the screen, keyboard, mouse, speakers), depending on what you start out with, you could even replace the 386 on the motherboard with a 486, and a weaker 486SX can be replaced with a better 486DX, the previous one can be sold off to cover expenses. You can also save a lot by skipping a CD-ROM drive, which would start at like $200 alone by 1994, Doom was available on floppies.

If you had already invested in a 386 prior, you didn't need to spend a fortune on getting decent performance with Doom, nor did you if you had a lower end 486. Some computers with 486s could also be upgraded to Pentium, which could become relevant for later games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563751
IP owners inevitably become out of touch over time.
To get into high positions in established companies of any kind, it is usually the case that you need to have a long and successful career in the business market. The higher ups are then either older men who worked themselves up over time or rich middle aged men who simply bought the company. It so happens that the older a company brand becomes the more out of touch with the consumer demand they become. The, for this problem specifically hired, market analyzing team only amplifies the whole process, as they have in most cases only raw numbers and data to go after. By chasing and misinterpreting raw data, they further distance themselves to the actual realistic customer demand that they had initially fulfilled. That is usually the case for any product oriented company with a fairly successful early stage growth rate.

My personal approach is to determine in a franchise, when and where the cracking points for passion and quality starts to substantially influence and negatively impact the end products. Then I simply ignore their mere existence in relation to the whole franchise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9567254
there's no real "first one" because there's no arbitrary limit that makes something a bullet hell or not. Stuff like DDP is considered by everybody to be a bullet hell, stuff like Tiger Heli definitely isn't, but Batsugun and Garegga are in a weird in-between, with some emphasis on micro-dodging from time to time, but with a fairly big hitbox, low bullet count and density, which makes them feel like prototypes for bullet hell.
Batsugun isn't even too different from V-V when it comes to bullets, and that came out a few months before, so that would make V-V the first one.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9567840
Tiger-Heli has more bullet curtains than most classic shmups to be honest, but I guess you are talking about patterns from a single enemy.

I think the main defining factor is small hitbox, which is intrinsic to all the gameplay and design surrounding it. To me, danmaku's signature style is a tiny little hitbox, slow bullets with tiny hitboxes, dull and static backgrounds, a shot covering a large portion of the screen (at least 50%), uninspired art and sound, and constant hordes of enemies littered without intent or care that just form a long flowing chain.

I would say Batusugun Original is only like 40% danmaku, and Batsugun Special is maybe 60%

It really is amazing just how much value you can get out of the PS1, even though the console is no longer $20 on average.
>loose PS1 current price = $35
>composite cable and power cable = $15 for the pair
>PS1 controllers = $12 each
>PS1 memory cards = $11 each
>PS1 modchip = $3 if you shop around
For $76 you can be playing the entire library if you know how to solder, $88 will let you bring a friend, and $99 will let him have his own memory card for his Diablo character. Another $16 gets you a Gameshark and the ability to fuck around with games and do stuff like skip the license tests in Gran Turismo. The only other retro home console that comes close in terms of value is the Sega Genesis with the $42 flash cart.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561476
>And less than 50 were built.

1993 was pre-internet so information is not available on the exact amount. However my research confirms around 25 to 30 Ridge Racer Full Scale Units were exported for Western/Foreign markets. They were spread across the USA, UK, Spain, France, Middle East, Australia, etc.

And around 20 Ridge Racer Full Scale were used in Asian markets. Namco themselves kept several units in reserve to use in their Namco branded theme parks and Namco arcades in Japan. Several independent arcade owners in Asia had a Ridge Racer Full Scale too. A few malls had them as well. In the 1990s, any business owner could buy it from Namco if they had the money.

Trust me. Namco would NOT invest money in a factory, put Ads in sales magazines (for arcade owners), make sales flyers, and only make a small handful of Ridge Racer Full Scale Units. You need bulk sales to make it worth the investment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563351
>are you sure? i saw one of these at pontins in prestatyn in late 90s/early 00s. If they only made 50 it's hard to imagine one would have ended up some run down holiday camp jn North Wales
No one knows the exact number for sure. Literally anyone with $250,000 to blow could have ordered a Ridge Racer Full Scale from Namco between 1993 and 1998. I'm not saying only 50 units were made. All I know is that I could only confirm around 50 with my research but more could have been made. It would not surprise me if more were manufactured.

Arcade collectors on forums like to say that only around 20 ridge racer full scale units were ever made, and pretend it was some sort of super rare machine. Which is complete bullshit. Namco would not invest millions into tooling an entire arcade factory and only make 20 units. They aren't Sega. Namco is actually well known for being financially responsible. It would not surprise me if 100 or 200 were made. I've talked to people that claim they saw Ridge Racer Full Scale in malls, movie theater lobbies, big arcades, theme parks, beach resorts, airports, etc.

>imagine one would have ended up some run down holiday camp jn North Wales
Your holiday camp probably bought them used at a big discount. During the early 2000s, many arcades were closing down because the arcade market crashed and never recovered. Businesses were selling their arcade machines on eBay and several websites for super cheap. That includes Ridge Racer Full Scale. I remember seeing them for sale. You could have gotten it for cheap if you had a few thousand dollars back then. I'm guessing a few places picked up a Full Scale for cheap and got a couple more years of use out of it until the machine broke down and was scrapped. Sucks that no one saved even one working unit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564774
Arcade business owners paid huge sums of money for arcade cabinets with the promise that they will earn their investment back in 6 months and start earning profit. Ridge Racer Full Scale was no different.

An arcade owner could pay $200,000 for Ridge Racer Full Scale. Yes that's huge for an arcade. But they could charge $5 dollars per play. Let's assume when it first came out that 500 people per day played Ridge Racer Full Scale. That $2,500 dollars a day. That's about $75,000 a month. That's $450,000 in 6 months. That's $900,000 in 1 year. It's already more than paid for itself.

I know you think these numbers are silly and absurd. But you don't understand. The 80s and 90s were a different time. Arcades were incredibly popular back then. A cultural phenomenon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9564825
Ah...these ski machines. These things used to be everywhere. There aren't many "old school" Namco or Sega ski arcade machines like Super Alpine racer around anymore in arcades.

These machines saw a lot of abuse. People were very rough on the machines and the foot mechanisms were prone to breaking without periodic maintenance. People slamming their whole body weight left and right would eventually cause something to break. Many of these machines would break down as years passed.

The rear projection screens also were an issue as time passed. The bulbs inside needed to be replaced after a certain amount of hours of use. The bulbs cost money, and arcade owners don't want to invest money in keeping the screen running. Especially when LCD technology is now available.

They are also very bulky. If you do see a ski machine in arcades, it's probably a new one made Raw Thrills.

I'm not saying these old school Namco or a Sega Ski Machines are rare to find...Or that they worth a lot of money. They are out there and You could definitely find one for sale if you want on some websites. But shipping is expensive and it will probably need some sort of maintenance done.

Many arcade owners simply got rid of them after several years rather than continue maintaining them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The late great Bob Pease of National Semiconductor, who was sadly killed in a 2009 car accident, didn't seem to think so. He said most ICs never get near a temperature high enough to cause internal failure. I read on a forum somewhere a guy who said he'd seen a chip die tested and still work at 660F (!) although the die would likely melt after at most an hour of that kind of extreme heat. The main materials that dies are made of, silicon and aluminum (copper in modern high performance applications) can tolerate temperatures way beyond what would be encountered in normal operating conditions.

Probably, although the anons saying the C64 is much more susceptible to voltage/power issues nuking the various chips are definitely correct. The original PSUs are literal timebombs. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560340
In fact a bad PSU will blow up the RAM before it harms any other components in the computer. The RAM chips have small, dense dies and are very easily damaged by overvoltage while the main chips like VIC-II et al have relatively large, coarse dies that can take a fair bit of abuse. So the RAM is basically like a crumple zone in a car frame; it will get toasted first and provide a warning of imminent PSU failure.

If you happen to find a C64 with bad RAM it's more often than not a PSU fault and an indication that you'd better throw that PSU away at once (occasionally you'll come across a machine with Micron RAM chips which do a fine job of self-destructing with no help needed).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562815
in fact the very earliest 6502s from 1975-76 were 8 um. over time MOS managed to shrink this some. the VIC-II as anon said was 5 um but also had substantially more transistors than a 6502. by the time C64 was in development, they had two main production lines running. the first was the NMOS line that couldn't do anything smaller than 5 um. there was another line that did 3 um HMOS. the large process nodes that VIC-II and SID used were outdated by the time Reagan was president but they were there and there was no point in not using them as the production line was there and the VIC-II and SID wouldn't benefit from die shrink as much as a CPU or RAM. also MOS had years of experience with the older large node NMOS process and the initial production run of VIC-II/SID in 1982 got something like 80% yields. by the time they'd moved to the plastic-shelled R2 VIC-II in early '83 it would have been better than 95% yields.

during this time Commodore was trying to go down to 2 um for CPUs and other such components. they had trouble getting it to work which resulted in the notoriously unreliable PLA and TED. a lot of these were faulty; the PLA had such low yields that they intentionally shipped C64s with defective ones to meet shipping quotas with the idea that they would be returned and swapped out for known good chips.

yes those large node processes were outdated, but since Commodore only made chips for in-house use and didn't have to be concerned with consumer demand as Intel and Motorola did, they didn't necessarily need to be aggressive about adopting the latest tech.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

CMOS was always better but in the early days ran really slowly. It took a while to figure out that you could speed it up by thinning the dopant layer (at the expense of making the chip more vulnerable to overvoltage).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563087
>during this time Commodore was trying to go down to 2 um for CPUs and other such components. they had trouble getting it to work which resulted in the notoriously unreliable PLA and TED. a lot of these were faulty; the PLA had such low yields that they intentionally shipped C64s with defective ones to meet shipping quotas with the idea that they would be returned and swapped out for known good chips.
Bil Herd claimed they had difficulty doping the wafers properly and applied too much dopant for the die size--this resulted in excessive conductivity and was visible on the die as "creeping crud" (his words). For contrast here's a section of an 8086 die. The transistors are dark purple from the dopant coating. What presumably happened with those TED chips was excess dopant oozing out onto the substrate.

As an EE, I say this has to be case-by-case. Throwing heat sinks around without reason can do more harm than good e.g. if they fall off and short the PCB.
Quality of IC manufacture, PCB/circuit design and tolerance to other part variation/failure are a few factors affecting IC life. True it is a waste of time for most instances, but a stoopid looking heat sink in the right place could help if a chip is poorly made, or could be subject to abnormal operating conditions. Any actual benefit, if any, will depend on the context

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I'm pretty sure it was Ironsword II. I was in grade 1 at the time and we were learn vowels for the first time only I not only understood the concept of vowels I correctly stated all the rules around them while all my classmates stared at the teacher blankly and/or picked their nose. My teacher was so impressed she wrote a note to my parents (probably figuring they were responsible). My mother rewarded me with my choose of any video game rental I wanted, I picked the on with Fabio on the box because it looked cool. I spent the whole night bouncing around like an idiot flicking my sword around the whole time looking for secrets, killing enemies and trying to figure out how to progress. Can't say how far I got as I don't remember what I do remember is that I missed the bus the next morning at a time my parents left me home alone in the morning but under the watch of the neighbours who immediately called my parents. My dad, who was closer, had to drive all the way home to pick me up and take me to school and I got grounded for a few days. The game was returned early of course but it didn't matter I think I got my 3 days worth in that one night.

THIS IS GTR.
It's a lot simpler than you think.
The good news is: You have no choice, you HAVE to start by building the trigger. The Red and Green blobs to the left in pic related is your trigger. IF you begin by building anything else you will screw up when receiving nuisance. Start with the trigger. You have to begin by the trigger. There is also a reason why you build left to right which puyo nexus explains in great detail so again you have no choice here, you HAVE to start with the trigger and it absolutely HAS TO be built on the right side of the screen.
Easy as fuck, right? Savestate so you can preview the pieces and build the GTR trigger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
TO REITERATE
You do this. That's your trigger. There is no other way, you have to start here first.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
NEXT
After building the trigger which you absolutely have to do first do your 2-2 stair pattern. This is your normal newb stairs we just split them in half so you get more horizontality.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
PUT IT TOGETHER
Your trigger + 2-2 and you will get this.

>>9557454
Legacy of Darkness with Reinhardt is legit one of my fav N64 games. KCE Kobe really laid down the ideal blueprint for 3D Castlevania despite its troubled development, the PS2 games got rid of everything that made their work ambitious and interesting.

>>9560076
>The problem is that it came out a couple months after OoT which shits all over it as an action/platformer with lite RPG elements.

It came out exactly two months after OoT and still runs way better than it. LoD in low res mode in particular is one smooth motherfucker.

Castlevania 64 is unique, even with all the "Zelda 64 inspirations". KCE Kobe did experiment with it a lot, which is exactly why it wasn't "intuitive" to play. It simply wasn't like other games from the genre at the time, so a lot of people trashed it just because it was unique. Heck, the character movement and animation in CV64 is actually ahead of most games from the era. And the level design is for the most part fantastic, matching each locale architecturally.

Plus the superb soundtrack and sound design, of course.

>>9568521
It's a long story anon, but it's an old urban legend of the internet that most likely started the "creepy pasta" fad. Basically, the joke of the day back in 1989 was that the Leisure Suit Larry series was finished. At the end of LSL3, he gets a job literally working for Sierra and lives in a log cabin with his wife. The end. Then there were some firings at Sierra that year of a couple notable individuals (who will not be mentioned, for fear of internet-sleuths finding me out), who were caught having a seance in the backrooms of the offices at 3:33 AM. Al Lowe, who was a practicing Methodist at the time, demanded they be fired. Shortly after, Sierra wanted a sequel to Leisure Suit Larry 3, which Al Lowe refused to do. Until a series of unfortunate misshaps occurred. According to sources, Al Low slept in one day an hour later than usual. When he tried to get ready to go to work and hurried out the door, he saw a piano had fallen on his car. The next week, on a busride back from the office, a man held the driver of the bus at knife point and almost stabbed Lowe, until a plain-clothes policeman arrested the would-be attacker. Bad shit continued to happen, and eventually Al Lowe decided he was getting someone upstairs angry for not using his talents, so began work on LSL4.

That's where the fun stuff begins. Almost immediately following the development of the coding for the game, it repeatedly had to be redone, as the code constantly got corrupted over and over again. Art assets would unknowingly disappear. Apparently late one night, Al Lowe stated he heard faint whisperings in the office and was so skeeved out he refused to work late nights anymore. He also heard tell of a man in black who would arrive in the office lobby, before anyone was at the office, when the doors were locked, at 5 AM on the dot for 2 weeks straight. In the end, the project collapsed as Al Lowe refused any further work on the project.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9569191
>did people back then complain about the difficulty or was it the norm?
I can't remember anyone claiming Super Mario was hard until maybe ten years ago. Back when it was first released, I'd say it was one of the easier games around.
The context was different. Games were more expensive back then. Most kids didn't have a lot of games. A lot of kids got only two games a year (birthday and Christmas). For this game in particular, it was bundled with the console, so it might be the only thing you had to play for months, aside from rentals.
And play you would, because there was no Youtube or Tiktok or Netflix or Disney+ - just cartoons on Saturday morning and a bunch of terrible reruns on TV the rest of the week. The very idea of being impatient to finish a game would have been absurd.
Anyway, I played this game so much as a kid that I can usually beat it with no deaths or warps. The only part I find hard to do consistently is the getting those extra lives from the Koopa on the steps in World 3. Not that I really love the game. 2 and especially 3 and World are a lot more fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few years ago I spent hours A/B testing my Wii against a Toaster NES. I fucking LOVE the NES so this is not a Zoomer opinion. There are two parts to the story. The TL;DR is that besides the slightly off scaling (that I wasn’t able to match) and a color palette that was a lot brighter (in a good way) I didn’t find any issues … UNTIL I SOLD MY NES.

Seems like I found all the problems once the hardware NES was gone. IN GENERAL, I don’t think you will be aware of it, however in some games (like Super C) the camera on the diagonal climbs in level one didn’t work properly. I remember finding other issues with some games (slow down, stuttering) but it wasn’t game breaking.

In short, keep your NES but use the Wii for convenience. Input lag wasn’t a huge issue on a CRT (you can use a wired controller too you casual).

SNES obviously doesn’t work perfect. Contrary to what anon said earlier in this thread, Starfox 2 doesn’t run correctly. Maybe it’s my rom but it was a bit weird when I tried it years back. Also, YOSHIS ISLAND is a meme test game, THE SNES TEST GAME IS MARIO RPG.

Mario RPG will skull fuck an emulator. And the wii SNES emulator does not run Mario RPG, HOWEVER most games are fine/perfect enough.

GBA runs like trash if you use VBAnext but MGBA seems to run every game at full speed, I never encountered any issues but I’ve only tried a couple of games. What didn’t work in VBANEXT worked in mGBA.

I played snatcher on the wii genesis emulator and I remember at some point I had to switch to another cause it was starting to lock up.

The Wii is perfect for gaming. Emulation accuracy is good enough for $50, native CRT support, massive library. Also as other anons point out the virtual console ports seem to remedy accuracy issues.

>Wii
Wii/GC
>PS3
PS1,PS2,PS3,PSP, EMULATION UP TO CPS3
>XBOX OG
XBOX OG GAMES
>PC/LAPTOP
Everything in between

^^^ This is the winning strategy.

Can I ask which emulator you used last? The latest builds for snes and nes are FCEUltraRX and Snes9xRX.

I grew up with Super C and didn’t recognize a problem with vertical scrolling when I tried it right now. Scrolling was always weird with the little white boarder on top even with real hardware. I did see definite graphical problems with the Cheetahmen intro for Action 52 and some possible gameplay bugs but that whole fucking game is a glitch so it’s hard to say if something is going wrong. I’ve heard others say Action 52 is the hardest NES game to emulate but it’s hard to agree when the game isn’t an official release.

I’ve been emulating since the Dingoo days so I know how Super Mario RPG was the holy grail of emulation for a long time. Tried it right now and found no obvious issues with stuttering or the menus. If you aren’t using Snes9xRX then you have to try Starfox 2. The nintendo logo has a tiny bit of stuttering but everything else plays great. Maybe it has some frame skip but the game overall is so choppy it’s hard to tell what’s intentional.

I’m not saying it’s perfect. On Mega Man X2 there’s a 1/4 second hiccup right before the intro miniboss fight. And in Sim Earth the intro sequence is rough. What I am saying is that I’m sure all these games can be played to completion, all the heavy hitters play great, I haven’t seen any games that just won’t load at all and that’s all a huge accomplishment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9566678
Tekken in the arcades was much cheaper than its competition. The first game was basically a PS1 advertisement before the console itself even came out due to running on the same hardware, and it was like a tenth of the price of a Virtua Fighter 2 cabinet.
This meant a lot more installs for those cabinets, especially outside of dedicated arcade halls.
As for the home ports the PS1 was just insanely popular and Tekken, especially 2 and 3, were some of the better 3D fighting games for it.
KI Gold was one of the more expensive home console games sold at the time at 80 bucks, Tekken games were closer to 50 and dipped all the way to 20 with Greatest Hits releases.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9566798
N64 games having high prices didn't necessarily translate to high profit
KI Gold was published by Nintendo so it's hard to say how much Rare ended up making per cart.
However for third parties would end up paying like 20 bucks per cart for even small ROMs, and KI Gold was one of the bigger early N64 games so it's probably closer to half that price being simply manufacturing costs.
Compare this to PS1 where a single disc would cost a couple bucks including royalties to Sony complete in shrinkwrap. So despite being half to a quarter of the retail price the per unit profit of Tekken was significantly higher.

- CRTs are no longer produced because they have inferior picture quality versus LCDs
- CRTs emit dangerous levels of X-rays or other forms of radiation
- CRTs always have easily-visible flicker
- CRTs always cause eyestrain
- CRTs always make a high-pitched squealing noise
- CRTs contain lethal amounts of electricity, even when unplugged
- CRTs need calibration more than two to three times a year
- Overall CRT black levels are not superior to LCDs because ambient light ruins CRT black levels
- Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
- Afterimages caused by phosphor decay are extremely annoying and are a significant downside of CRTs
- Sending an improper mode (resolution or refresh rate) to a CRT can cause permanent damage
- CRTs cannot have touchscreens
- 4:3 is so bad that nobody should use a non-widescreen CRT
- The Sony GDM-FW900 is the only CRT worth owning
- Curved CRTs have objectively inferior picture quality versus flat CRTs with otherwise equal specifications
- CRTs should not be used because they are heavier and deeper than LCDs
- CRTs have severe reflections because they do not have matte coats
- CRTs can be permanently damaged by nearby magnets
- You will not have sex in 2023
- Analog signals limit a CRT's resolutions and refresh rates and negatively effect picture quality
- Heavy metals are used in CRT glass to reduce radiation

> Analog CRTs have more processing time than digital LCDs due to poor RAMDAC performance
perhaps true for graphics cards and monitors, but that is the fault of the graphics card, not the CRT.
an NTSC signal directly drives the electron beam. it don't get no faster than that. video game consoles used a technique called "double strike" to get 240p instead of 480i, essentially sending an invalid NTSC signal to get the beam to draw the same lines instead of alternating. hence those scanny ass scanlines.
> CRTs cannot have touchscreens
they sure as fuck did, and they existed since the early 80s. they were common on ATM machines.

seriously be careful if you decide to fuck around inside of one.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9550859
It's functionally identical to an F-type connector that you typically associate with RF input. It's the same signal just shaped differently.

Any RF box will do. Or actually, you don't even need a box; the purpose of that box was so that you could hook up your console without having to give up access to your TV channels. But since analogue TV isn't a thing anymore, it's a moot point. For instance you can just hook a Nintendo or Atari straight into the coax port without a box and it'll work just fine (actually better since less chance of interference from a shitty box)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9558619
completely normal, especially for the top and bottom. its called overscan. you'll notice most old games don't have status bar information in the very top and bottom of the screen because of this reason.
a little bit is fine and normal: about 8 pixels or one square in any direction. just center it the best you can.
FCEUX by default cuts off the top and bottom 8 pixels of the screen by default, it was assumed TVs just were this way.
WARNING: you don't want to go crazy adjusting it either: if you make it perfect for your NES, your SNES and PlayStation will be out of whack, etc etc. analog signals were never perfect.

i took some pics to compare 16:9 mode anamorphic widescreen vs letterboxing.
i don't have any /vr/ games that do anamorphic widescreen, 240p or 480i, so here's a wiiu setting screen, connected to an sd flat screen tube (it needs some adjustment) that does 16:9 mode. the wiiu is here set to output 480i onto a 4:3 screen, which it automatically letterboxes. the result is that the picture is displayed in 360 horizontal lines.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: and here's the same screen but with the wiiu set to output 480i anamorphic widescreen, and the tv set to 16:9 mode. this shrinks the vertical deflection so all 480 horizontal lines are used to display the picture. all wiiu examples are over component

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: here's a close-up of star fox zero's title screen letterboxed. i don't know if the wiiu internally renders at 360 or renders at higher and then downscales.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: and the same but in 16:9 mode. as for how it looks in person, the flicker is less in 16:9 mode, and the "scanlines" (black spaces) aren't as apparent. interlacing artifacts (because it's one frame per field, not sure what the terminology is) also seem to be less apparent in 16:9 mode, but i don't know why that would be. as far as picture quality goes, the difference didn't seem that big. noticeable only if you're looking for it. i'd say see for yourself if you have the option.

you might live in an area where there just aren't many crts, but here are some more options:
-check your listings daily for several months, including curb alerts, garage/yard sales (if such things exist where you live), and estate sales
-create a wanted/buying listing on craigslist
-expand your search area and do a road trip
-ask your friends and relatives if they have any laying around
-see if you can't get any from a local recycling facility, including any organizations that accept electronic donations for reuse
-thrift stores, although some don't accept crts anymore
-flea markets and swap meets
if all that fails or if it's easier, you could pay ebay price and hope the seller packages it properly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9565176
>So PVM is just an even better Trinitron?
"Trinitron" is a brand of CRT. "PVM" is a line of Sony monitors, some of which contain Trinitron CRTs, with others using flat panel LCDs or OLEDs.
>They're pretty small though
Sony made PVMs ranging from 8 inches all the up to 42 inches. They also have a line of BVMs which go up to 32 inches.
>I guess the trade-off is you have to choose between great image and larger screen, or even better image and smaller screen?
Other way around actually. Larger PVMs typically have better image quality, though, image quality has little to do with screen size. Resolution/dot pitch is what matters. Typically, though, the smaller the screen the lower the resolution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9565779
Use something you can run 240p test suite on or maybe a dvd with test patterns on it.
Is the picture dim at max brightness? Does it have color purity issues?
Is the geometry good? Do lines look like lines and circles look like circles? Does the image look tilted?
How is the convergence? It's typical to have problems but is it noticeable if you're not looking at a test pattern?
Some of this stuff is fixable if you know what you're doing, but I'd avoid anything with big geometry problems or a dim picture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Atari were always most comfortable in the arcade style and could never really adjust when games started to get deeper.

An element of that is the fact that they never seemed to understand how integral decent music and sound are to the home gaming experience so they always treated it as an afterthought. The 7800 used the same sound chip as the 2600. The Lynx was touted as having a 32-bit sound processor, but in practice seemed like only a minor sonic upgrade from the 2600/7800. Even on the Jag, stuff like the soundtrack in Tempest 2000 was the exception. Many Jag games didn't even bother with music at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561389
>The Lynx was touted as having a 32-bit sound processor, but in practice seemed like only a minor sonic upgrade from the 2600/7800
It had an 8 bit 4-channel DAC which could be switched into PSG mode. It could sound nearly as nice as the SNES sound chip provided you gave it good samples. Most Lynx games use the PSG sound mode, perhaps to save some ROM. But in DAC mode, it sounds great.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2NJOJ9roJ9E
>Many Jag games didn't even bother with music at all.
Most Jag games were distributed in 2MB carts. Most developers were too lazy or too poor to hire good musicians to compose great sounding sampled music for them. Tempest 2000 was an exception.

>>9565716
Its got tons of games, so let me recommend you the games the NES couldn't possibly replicate instead. There's not even a NES equivalent for Star Raiders, atari's 1979 killer app on an 8 bit cart. The sequel looks even more impressive. There's star luster for the NES, but it looks horrible and plays worse. LucasArts 3D fractal games are also excellent, the NES couldn't run any of them. posts.name: Anonymous

>>9566841
>atari 8-bit is atari's 8-bit line of home computers
It was built for gaming. It had sprite system, projectile system, 4 channel sound chip, cart slot, and some BASIC clone that sucked because Atari cheaped out on that.
>it was the only powerful 8-bit home computer until commodore 64 came along. both C64 (commodore 64) and atari 8-bit is the only powerful 8-bit computers of the 80s
Now that's stupid. Yes the Atari 8-bit and C64 had a powerful sprite system, but others had their own strengths. The BBC Micro was a 6502 computer clocked at a whopping 2MHz, Elite ran smooth as a butter on it. ZX Spectrum could update its screen faster than any bitmap graphic home computer of its days. The CPC was, I think, the only 8 bit computer with no colour attribute limitations, and it was pretty fast too considering what it was. The PC-88 had a really high screen resolution.
But yes, for gaming purposes, nothing beat the Atari 8-bit and C64.
>if you mean atari st's processing speed then yes, it is far powerful than amiga
Of course, blast processing beats the 'migger.

More importantly, Critical Mode is bad in BBS/DDD when it isn't in 2 and 3 specifically because it only compounds the issues with BBS/DDD's mechanics. Because of how the flow of combat works in command deck games, you're probably not going to notice how mechanically bad the games are on Proud because you can bruteforce your way through them. But on Critical? Oh you better fucking believe you're going to notice what a bad idea it was to make enemies immune to stagger when you aren't in a powerup state or using something like Magnet/Zero Gravity/Balloon, on top of bullshit like enemies going into invincibility phases where they WILL twoshot you if they hit you in Critical so now all you can do is spam the evasion move that gives full iframes until they're done sperging out and go into the phase where you can hit them.
2 and 3 don't have this problem, because they are mechanically solid under the surface, the added difficulty on top of the bonuses only serves to complement the game's combat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9567906
>The downsides are cost and inability to use the MPEG card since the Satiator uses the same slot. There are only a few games that use it though, and at least one of those games has a patch to not need it (Lunar).

Is that really a big loss though? From what I understand it's both hard and expensive to even find a MPEG card that's not a bootleg, which apparently can be glitchy compared to the real thing.

And only about a dozen games were even made that support it, all of them Japanese-only and most of them just radio dramas or a set of videos rather than being actual games. The actual games IIRC all had non-MPEG versions too.

I think the bigger point of the card was that it allowed the Saturn to be a VideoCD player. A feature that was probably useful in early/mid 90s in Japan, not so much today in 2023 USA.

You're right though that the Fenrir is considerably cheaper, I didn't know it was that much less than the others. I also assumed it was by that asshole who made GDEMU and thus impossible to get.

Interesting though, looking at pictures of the Fenrir PCB, it's just an ESP32? The Xstation seems to be the same, just an ESP32 on a fairly empty board with some voltage circuitry. At least, the 20 and 21 pin versions of the Fenrir are pretty empty, the duo 20+21 pin version has additional ICs that I assume are to route the proper connections from either cable, and strangely is CHEAPER than the single-cable versions for some reason.

That ESP32 is starting to become the de-facto hardware to put in such devices lately, it's even used in the Memcard PRO, with the latest version completely removing the FPGA and relying entirely on the ESP32.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9563992
>>9563995
>>9564005
>Westerners seeked a challenge, magazines rated games based on difficulty (the higher the difficukty, the better the "longetivity" note)
That's partly true, but another reason is because of the advent of game rentals—which wasn't really a thing in Japan. If Japanese studios made games so easy that American kids were able to simply rent and beat over the weekend, they'd have no reason to purchase those games, which loses the money for the devs and publishers over time. In response, they made the American versions of games harder (and sometimes in bullshitty unfair ways) so that you'd need more than a weekend rental to beat the game. You'd actually need to buy it.

>>9565010
"rentals" is one factor but does not nearly explain it all. These days the idea that reviewers and players alike were seeking a challenge is such an alien concept, so hard to fathom, that people like to 'blame' difficulty of older games onto "rentals", as a way to say "it was intended bad design to fuck with the player", just so they can feel better about sucking or using cheats.
Yet, there are countless proofs that this mentality was real in the west, pic related being one (longetivity score, and thus the game's overall score being tied to challenge), or Japanese devs interviews explaining that very difference in mentality.
In Europe rentals weren't nearly as developed as in the US, it even quickly became banned in some countries. Yet, they still got the more difficult version of games in many cases; even when that version was a unique version (for instance Castlevania 3 which has 3 different difficulty, Europe difficulty being harder than Japanese). There is also the case of Battletoads, an European game made easier for the Japanese market.
As I was saying, rentals are one factor but do not cover it all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Is it autistic to use filters with a CRT computer monitor? I was looking for something to make it look like a consumer CRT since games just look a little too sharp on my current setup. Not really a fan of seeing sharp pixels.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9566349
You have a couple of options. You can use a preset such as tvout+interlacing, which, combined with a superwide 480p resolution such as 3840x480, should give you something that looks like 240p, and you can then add horizontal blur on top of that to give it a softer look. Pic related was taken using just such a setup. However, be aware that you'll likely have massive scanline gaps, which most older consumer CRTs didn't have, at least not this pronounced.

You can also try running your monitor at 1280x960 and dicking around with the various CRT shaders, but they're not exactly made with CRT monitors in mind since they're made to work with LCD subpixels to draw the simulated phosphor mask, whereas your CRT already has a mask of its own, so results may not be ideal unless you turn off phosphor mask emulation entirely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Should I use shaders/scanlines in PCSX2 if I'm playing at 3x native res?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9568419
Shaders are meant to replicate the effect CRTs had in which they could make a game's native resolution look better, so if you're upscaling there's not much point to it from an authenticity point of view.
But still, if it looks cool regardless, then why not. You do you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9568419
No. CRT shaders at heart are, in their own way, a fancy way to upscale a native resolution picture so it looks better when output on a high resolution display, so when you're already rendering at a higher-than-native resolution, there's little or nothing the CRT shader will actually do other than maybe add a phosphor mask and some cosmetic things like curvature. Even at native resolution, though, given the PS2 normally outputs at 448i (and sometimes 448p, either natively or through the use of game-specific progressive scan patches), you need at least 4K to get an appreciable CRT effect. There IS an argument to be made for using CRT shaders along with downsampling, which renders the game at higher-than-native resolution and then scales it back down to native output resolution, which will result in a much smoother, anti-aliased image, however.

>>9561779
>That's it? You just want the special move to take time to perform? An experienced player will do it as fast as just pressing b, in the end whoever practiced inputs the most will have the advantage instead of whoever uses their specials more wisely.
You're not going to see the point because you're not used to playing fighting games with another person who is able to apply enough pressure that the speed of the Shoryuken coming out actually matters. Using it as an anti-air is one thing, but doing it during the gap in a sequence of attacks, to avoid being pressured as you're getting up from the ground or as a way to knock them down immediately when they try to approach are the type of strategies special motions are meant to both limit and give more meaning to: those are all things that can be hard even for experienced players to perform when the outcome of a round hinges on it, given that fighting games tend to be very fast, and mapping the attack to a single button press, even with caveats (such as reducing i-frames) would reduce some of the complexity to the decision of doing so. More importantly, it's a way of making the game easier that also makes it more boring, and doesn't really help novice players have fun either, as it gives them less stuff to improve in and ignores the fact that they already have the option of playing in an environment where fucking up basic inputs doesn't matter nearly as much, i.e. against other beginners.
>>9561803
>So why not cut the grind? I don't care about the execution I care about the strategy

Fighting games, much like their namesake implies, are all about emulating the exhilaration of going mano a mano with someone else, and the difficulty of executing under pressure & pulling off shit you trained for are one part of what makes the combat and strategy in them have meaning. You could always play stuff like Samsho or pick easier characters too

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9561959
Why? Even in platformers there are "basic moves" with somewhat complicated inputs. The triple jump in 3D Mario games is kinda hard to do at first, it requires some pretty precise timing. It's balanced around that, it's a move that lets you go very high and far so it's a little tricky to do in order to reward players who master the timing.

Then there are perfect guard mechanics seen in fighting games but also other genres like Mario RPGs and action games like Devil May Cry or Dark Souls, where you have to press the block button within around a tenth of a second of an attack hitting to parry and counter. Or delay combos in DMC where you need to leave gaps of a precise length of time between each press of the attack button to get the right combo to come out.

Lots of games gate certain moves behind execution requirements.

I don't care for Street Fighter, but in the case of Ryu for instance he has several versions of his specials depending on which button you press after the input. As for the rest... yeah, no, you can play other people all you want and while you're gonna improve there's just some things you won't be able to learn unless you go online and look it up. It's not only about the execution, there's a fuckton of interactions between attacks and characters that you have to learn if you want to be able to consider yourself ''good'', while watching other people play can also help you improve a lot.

I heard the Power Rangers: Battle for the Grid game had simplified special inputs like in Smash, so that might be up your alley. I'm new to the genre but I'd never trade the balancing act inputs let you put in your game for the simplified controls on something you can learn in 30 minutes. The kinds of players that are virulently compative about needing simplified inputs aren't going to stick with something like old-school Guilty Gear, so who even cares?

inputs in fighting games used to be too hard. the average player understanding the dragon punch motion, practicing it, and still constantly getting errant qcf moves coming out was bad, being unable to play spd characters as a rule was bad. in the latter half of the 90s fighting game devs solved this problem by gradually moving to more lenient input buffers that required the player to still be constrained by the process of going through the motion states of the move but without the grueling accuracy that lead to constant failed inputs. sometimes casualization is warranted and sometimes it is not, the modern case of complaining about fighting game inputs is not warranted*.

None of the current console controllers have analog face buttons, d-pad or shoulder buttons ala PS2 and OG Xbox.
Nintendo have not even had analog triggers since the GCN (the first CC on Wii was the last to have them but was later replaced with the CC Pro).

Dreamcast taking away Z and C *without replacing them with shoulder buttons* was an arse backwards last minute decision. They're present in the API, several third party controllers have them and they're functional in certain games i.e. pressing the C button in SA1 makes the character stare at you.

>But analog triggers are a good thing in my POV. They are discrete shoulder buttons that act just like that until the aspirant player try a racing game and learns their magical thing spontaneously
Depends on the triggers. The GC triggers have an enormous amount of travel and relatively high resistance so they work poorly as digital triggers. The Wii Classic Controller and PS2 shoulder buttons are analog but the triggers are very shallow so it's hard to be precise with analog inputs.
I think the Xbox controllers and the DS4 ultimately struck the best balance. And what the Dualsense is doing with adaptive resistance is very interesting too.
