I live in Japan and I go to thrift stores occasionally to pick up games to play. Over the past few years I've watched the prices steadily climb and it's really sad to see. But it's not all games. Mostly it's the stuff that importers want, like Pokemon and Chrono Trigger.

A few years ago you could get all of the old Pokemon games CIB for under $10, but now they sell for much more and they get locked in a case with the rare games now. The other day I saw a CIB copy of Pokemon Blue for over $100, that was insane. A lot of old RPGs that used to be like $3 CIB have also climbed in price for CIB versions (but loose versions are pretty cheap still).

I'm not really affected by it since I already have a lot of the games that I care about, but I have this attitude that games are for playing so I'm bothered by this the same way I'm bothered by graded games. Ok let this isn't Mario or whatever, you can't play an RPG if you don't know Japanese and the majority of import fags don't. These guys are buying these just to put on a shelf and collect dust as a display piece because they can't afford a copy in their own language and they need it as an excuse to justify emulation. Meanwhile Japanese gamers who largely rely on buying/reselling to thrift shops (a lot of people don't have space for large collections) are stuck with the higher prices.

You ruined your own game market already. Don't ruin other game markets.

Good post. Agree with everything.

Collector-types have always existed but what I think is new here is the commodification of it towards the masses through YT and social media, this mixes in with two phenomena:
First, weird late-stage capitalism precariousness where people live in precarious conditions but are materially wealthy: they have enough money to buy comparatively cheap materials that hold sentimental value but not enough money to make big purchases such as homes, cars, healthcare etc so their disposable income goes towards this, e.g. 30-something hikkineets living in their mother's basement have just enough to collect vidya but not enough to move out and start a family and it becomes a vicious circle.

Secondly, but it's also linked to the first is that the current generation of young adults isn't growing out of childhood. They want to keep consuming the same things they consumed in the 80/90/00s, it's not unusual to see these types making 5 hour essays on Pokemon Yellow or Tokimeki Memorial like they're some grand cultural achievements.

Of course like you said there's all these richfags flexing their collection online and this makes others want to emulate them. Everything is a hustle, everything is an opportunity to make money.

>weird late-stage capitalism precariousness
Not to get too /pol/ here, but if you think late-stage capitalism is so bad, you're completely unprepared for the horrors of late-stage communism, or even the post-communism being experienced in what will probably be known in a few years as the "warring states" section of Europe. It's such a meme to use a term like "late-stage capitalism" when the "early-stage" capitalism of the industrial revolution was much worse. Real late-stage capitalism is capitalism augmented by socialism which is what they have in Europe, what is distressing us in the US is crony capitalism, not the "late-stage capitalism" that Twitter made up.

As far as the rest of your point goes, I think it's less that people live in precarious conditions and more that they're just retarded; yes, there are certainly a lot of destitute people that live off of handouts and actual scraps (usually victims of workplace industrial accidents that end up homeless in the end), but your average "gamer" kidult should be able to "buy" a new car by just saving money for a down payment instead of blowing every paycheck on vidya and drugs. Even back in the day boomers bought all their luxuries on credit, but most millennials have no idea how to get started with that stuff and don't want to know.

>the current generation of young adults isn't growing out of childhood
I don't really think this is a generational thing as I've met many people older than me that act like high schoolers, the difference now is that we've had The Big Bang Theory (or whatever scapegoat you prefer) normalize the consumer part of being a nerd (buying shit), so there's less stigma against (some!) nerdy activities. Also people like that tend to be on the techy side of things since they're still nerds somewhat, so employers put up with them due to there being a shortage of IT specialists, so you end up with these people wanting to buy nerdy kids' toys being empowered by high salaries.

You know who told me that? Not someone at my high school during senior year, not someone at my university, it was anons on /g/ discussing degrees, and I happened to pick up that information from them during senior year of high school. But most people perceive uni as "I went here for four years, give me a job", they don't understand that you're supposed to use your campus's career resources and go to parties/hangouts to network with your classmates. Metas like that aren't taught in US schools.

>>9568110
>the shift from wanting to move up the corporate latter and amass wealth to valuing a work/life balance
Corporate jobs just used to be way more fun back in the day; there'd be a lot of drinking parties, plus holiday parties were really extravagant instead of just the boring buffets we get now, not to mention all the various proper benefits your job would give you. There were proper incentives to try hard at the office because your company would take care of you. But most of that went away during the 2008 crash, and due to the recent inflation it is now more profitable to work casually for two to three years at a place before moving elsewhere for a higher paycheck instead of sweating at a place for five for a CHANCE, not a guarantee, of a promotion. And when your place of work doesn't provide you with all these nice things people would get twenty years ago, of course people would prioritize their life over their work.

>>9555378
That's entirely on Nintendo of America.

By the time Super Bomberman 3 released in Japan, Hudson Soft USA was closed and had to cancel localizations for Super Bonk 2 and Elfaria (possibly in collaboration with Working Designs, but Hudson would still publish)

Nintendo chose to pick up Super Bomberman 3 and Nintendo of America staff worked on the localization and game testing (there's even footage in a Japanese documentary) much like with Terranigma, they just chose to release it only in Europe.

It's not too weird, because NoE was still a subsidary of NoA and translators were really discouraged from learning Japanese directly (not that it kept them from doing it anyways, and the Japanese staff from appreciating it, and for them to eventually get their autonomy to reduce the +1 year release schedule gaps), but Nintendo of America's weird insistence on killing the SNES as soon as 1995 was something. Metal Warriors by LucasArts was supposed to be a Nintendo-published game too, and they planned an English localization of DBZ Super Butoden 2 (simply called Dragon Ball) in 1996 meant for Mexican audiences.

>>9555689
Scandinavia has its own Nintendo distribution. When Nintendo was busy getting fucked over by Atari (failed 1983 American Famicom launch as rebranded Atari, Atari intended to bury Nintendo alive by sitting on the rights all along, Nintendo headhunted some of those Atari marketing teams and tried to slowly piece together its own distribution) and Mattel/Bandai (European distribution until 1993), the Scandinavian branch was the only one actually doing its job, and even getting titles sooner than other regions.

posts.com:
>>9565940
Focus mosty on the Monk. Good stat growth per level, amazing skills (Chakra and Revive especially, group healing and reviving without needing to use MP or items) and hits hard as fuck even without being able to equip weapons. But also make sure to get a few Ninja levels (or change the character's class to Ninja and send them on errands to gain skill points without gaining any class experience and forcing the character to level up), the goal is to amass 900sp to spend on the dual-wielding ability, Two Swords. Then go back to the Monk or whatever other class. The skill name would make you think it affects swords only, but it makes you able to dual-wield any weapon on any character. For the Monk class, it makes you hit twice. You'll be an unstopable juggernaut. So yeah OP, Monk. But if you like another class, go for it, just get that Ninja skill either way - trust me, you'll want it. Oh and Ramza is honestly a jack of all trades, you can make him into anything and he'll still kick ass. I had a very fun playthrough with Geomancer Ramza as an example.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9566274
For magic users, yes. But you don't wanna level up as the Calculator, you want all of his skills, then use his skillset as the secondary one maining Black Mage or Time Mage or whatever. Terrible stat growth if you level up as the Calculator. And the way to use him is kinda like super lite programming - if condition X is met, use skill Y on everyone meeting said criteria, otherwise Z. So you can use Level (elevation) as an example - you start the map, everyone (both your team and the enemy) starts mostly on elevation level 5 (the large number on the right hand side of the screen whenever you highlight a tile) let's say, move all of your dudes one level down or up as soon as possible, when it's your magic user's turn - "use fire magic on all enemies on tiles 5 levels high", boom, you can clear an entire map like that in a few turns.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Ninja
Mostly I just like ninjas. Their secondary abilities aren't that great. I'd be nice if you could use vanish to sneak around the battlefield and use surprise attacks on enemies while being un-targetable yourself, but it almost never plays out that way. If you like using AI/auto battle, you never want to learn anything other than the bombs and shurikens or kiss your hard earned items goodbye.

>Monk
Really strong attacks, can restore HP/MP whenever he wants to to himself and others. Bonus: give him dual wield and watch him hit motherfuckers twice for like 500 a swing.

>Dark Knight
Obligatory because it's an overpowered job and if you grew up on the PSX version it seems like this should've been in the game originally somehow.

>Samurai
You might think this is a melee job, but it's one of the best jobs for a high faith character. The abilities have a lot of variety and cost zero MP to use. The katanas don't break that often. Really the only drawback is it can be expensive

>Calculator
I've never mastered one, but I'm skeptical about how good these are. Could be a case of autismos screeching about it because numbers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9555159
It's possible to force your switch to use the 1.0.0 version of Atari 50 that has Warbirds still in it. The issue is, you need to do a factory reset on your switch. As long as you've let a physical game update, you can't run that game ever in the future without having at least that update. There's some sort of data that remains after you delete data that tells the switch you NEED to update before you can play. Factory reset is the only way to clear that data. Factory reset your switch, then take it offline and put the cartridge in and install the game and disable auto-updates for that game, then your switch should have Atari 50 with Warbirds and can be safely taken back online.
I know your anger, I felt it the day I brought home a PS2 and MGS3 Substance and was all excited to play Metal Gear Online, only to find out they shut the servers down a few months prior.

>>9556962
>This could effect all games on all consoles btw. What's to stop them from sending updates like this to all other collections or standalones? The future looks grim.

It's actually much worse than that. When it becomes sufficiently practical, and eventually it will, mainstream single-player games will not only be online-only but streaming-only. The general public will embrace the convenience of paying a subscription to access all the games in a provider's library, without having to worry about disk space, let alone shelf space. This all-you-can-play model will take the edge off how they don't actually *own* anything in that library, whose contents are subject to change without notice.

There will be nothing for us to back up, unpatch, crack, pirate, or preserve, because all the code and assets will be out of reach on some corporate cloud server. You will have no recourse when they change a game, retire it, or revoke your access for whatever reason.

No matter how digitally locked down they are, movies, music, and ebooks can at least be recorded through the analog hole (i.e. filming the screen), but games will be at the absolute mercy of rightsholders.

t. Cassandra

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9560002
The Lynx has a custom 16 bit 16Mhz CMOS handling the sprites and rendering the graphics, and a 4Mhz 65C02 (clocked faster than the SNES CPU) handling the general game logic. It also has a dedicated math ASIC that could transform the sprites quickly or something like that. Not even the SNES or Genesis could match the Lynx's performance, let alone the 7800. It's a low res amiga on steroids.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I dunno why people call it the videogames crash of 1983-1985 or 1984. Consoles and arcades were in a decline starting in 1980. Computer gaming was on the rise during the same period. All thanks to the new cheap micro-computers like the Apple II, Atari ST, C64, etc. Computer gaming hit a slump in 1985 until 1988-89 when VGA started getting widespread and not just cutting edge. Consoles hit a slump themselves in 1993 and didn't recover until 1996, and arcades were going down in profits during the same time. Never hear anyone talk about the computer videogames crash of 1985-1988 or the videogames crash of 1993-1996.
The only difference is there was a major recession in the early 1980's. So somehow the recession-related cutback on customer spending is a major videogames crash event, but all the other times the industry has seen their market get cut in half is business as normal. And Nintendo is somehow the savior of videogames for launching the NES at the start of an economic boom period. Never hear anyone say Sid Meier, Jordan Mechner, or Al Lowe saved computer gaming for the growth in PC gaming in 1989.

Maybe the mainstream will be fugged as you say, but physical will still remain an option as the past two decades have proven against all odds.

That one move alone would let Sony (or anyone else) pull out the fucking rug from underneath any competitor trying to do Stadia 2: Electric Jiggaboo, and all the cost and effort required by them would be to do what has always worked very well for them in the past.

>B: Set out on the quest to build the massive global infrastructure required to even barely support your competing Suckotron 5000, only to get sidelined by the other parties who weren't retarded enough to do this

It can only ever be dead in the water because you're leaving yourself open to any competitor to trivially have a massive and tangible edge against you which you can never overcome, option A is too profitable to not be your choice. The only way videogames would ever come the point of not having any other option would be if there was some sort of international Video-Hitler enforcing a Stadia cartel at gunpoint.

If you look at the history of both companies, Namco was always #1 in terms of sales. But it was an INTENSE rivalry.

>>9561908
>Alpha 3 and Darkstalkers 3 don't have to load up four characters at a time.
And? My point is that these ports are ok. What's yours? We settled for much less during the 16-bit generation so having A3 and D3 at home at this quality was great. Especially since Saturn versions stayed in Japan.
>The N64 with the expansion pak has 8MB of unified RAM.
Unified RAM doesn't help when texture cache is only 4kb and bottlenecks the whole system when it has to be explicitly asked to constantly fetch new data from RAM. PS1 texture cache on the other hand is an associative cache so it takes no CPU cycles to be updated and VRAM size is the only limit.
In short, N64 port of a Capcom fighting game can have arcade perfect animation stored in RAM but actually displaying it at real time would stall the whole thing.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9562570
It had other problems, Nintendo's certifications were too rigid for anything but racing games to allow the z-buffer to be disabled. Due to the tight restrictions and bottlenecks on the N64 thanks to its memory layout and how GPU access would cost CPU cycles it could only outperform the PS1 in sandboxed tests which are the exact opposite of how games function.

PS1 had the most reasonable solution for 3D at the time and it shows, games made in 1994 and games made in 2000 literally look a generation apart on the console. 1996 N64 games vs 2001 N64 games, kinda like switch 2017 vs 2022, don't look significantly improved. They are better but not to the point it's really obvious because there simply wasn't much to wring out of the console.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562198
Ok, since you guys continue to insist, let's check MK Trilogy closely.
First of all, MK games have simplistic backgrounds with many tiling and repeating elements. Compare this with CPS2 games that have more big and unique, sometimes animates objects in their backgrounds.
Next, the chatacters animations. MK Trilogy sprites are very thin and don't have much unique animations. SF Alpha games are kind of simple too but Darkstalkers and Marvel vs games have more elaborate attack animations that take a large chunk of screen (and VRAM). MK Trilogy being this lightweight on animations is pretty much confirmed by the PS1 version: it easily holds 4 unique characters for 2 on 2 combat in PS1 RAM - when one character is defeated the game doesn't stop to load the second one from the disc. No Capcom game manages to have four complete and unique characters in a single fight on PS1 because they take much more memory than Mortal Kombat ones.
N64 has more RAM and doesn't have to deal with loading from the disk at all, so it allows SIX unique characters in 3 on 3 combat. Great, right? But here's the deal: the animation quality is worse than in PS1 version. So while there are six characters in N64 RAM, even having only two of them on screen, N64 can't animate them as fast as PS1 version. >N64 could use the cart rom chip like RAM and stream data much faster than any optical media console on the market
And just to add to this, no cart based system actually does this. It still has to use RAM or different caches in between. The question is how fast can it fetch the data? Not to mention that many N64 games had to use compressed graphics so the system had to take the data from the cart, then uncompress it to RAM and only then it could use it. It wasn't free.
The system that operates very similar to what you describe is Neo Geo. I don't remember exact details but SNK didn't bother with ROM sizes and memory costs and used the biggest ones available because they could sell the carts at a big cost anyway. And then NG architecture allowed them to stream the graphics from ROM to RAM almost for free. N64 was built with different strengths in mind (fast 3D scene calculations) and it wasn't optimized to toss large sprites around with the same ease.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So CPS2 games use frame skipping to enable their turbo modes. The higher turbo mode the more frames are skipped.
But instead you could do this in reverse. You can run the gameplay logic at 60 fps internally while only displaying 50 fps sprite updates but stretching out the time the frame is on screen to make the gameplay speed still the "normal" speed*. This won't have much of an effect on the visual appearance of the game because sprites are often held on screen for multiple frames anyway so rarely will an important frame get skipped. It would result in some animations being longer than normal.**

There were other tricks used in the PS1 ports that should work here. Changing the hit sparks to 3d graphics is the first thing. The life bars could also be 3d. That's a little bit of memory savings. I think you could probably do something for the in-game timer to make it out of 3d graphics as well. Not numbers but maybe something like a two colored wheel that runs out.

*Tournament players would cry about the slowness but it is what it is.
**This would make occasional differences to the gameplay by having a move be one or two more frames of animation longer on screen resulting in something that would usually be safe on block to be punishable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9563434
>It would result in some animations being longer than normal.**
Thinking over it again the animations would be the same length but what you would do is repeat the same sprite as before or after the sprite you frame skipped over.

So if you were doing a 1/6 frame skip you'd skip every sixth frame and replace it with either the frame in front of it or behind it. You could make this alternate if you wanted, or come up with more elaborate plans.
I *think* this should result in a significant saving of resources without making too much of a hit on the gameplay since the arcade version is typically played in "Turbo" mode that employs a frame-skip. So players are used to that and accept it. But here instead of using the frame skip to increase gameplay speed you're keeping the same speed but saving resources to free up time for the N64 hardware to keep up.
Again, this does result in the game running in what in the arcade version is the slow "normal" speed option.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Interesting thread that is probably related.
https://www.reddit.com/r/EmuDev/comments/ug5ere/about_texture_caches/

>I wrote a texture cache for an emulator many years ago when we were emulating Primal Rage on the Xbox. The total size of the textures were larger than the total amount of ram available on the Xbox so we compressed each texture using deflate and then loaded and unpacked them as they were needed. I used a simple linked list of textures and every time a texture was used it was moved to the head of the texture list. I used a map to quickly locate which textures were already unpacked in memory and which ones needed to be loaded from the CD. When a texture needed to be loaded, the last used texture (at the tail of the linked list) was discarded and the new texture was asynchronously loaded & unpacked and added to the head of the linked list.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
DingDongwhatchi?.. just more cookie-cutter, boring "shots-everywhere" junk to BORE me to TEARS, sorry. Last one of these new games I tried was Ikaraga... Sorry! but I learned to play color-matching games when I was two, don't need to do it anymore! Deleted THAT computer application from my Dell desktop after about 20 minutes.

R-Type, Gradius, Darius... those classics are a little more up MY alley. No TINY hitboxes to make the game look harder than it is, no half-naked japanimation cartoon girls, no gimmicky scoring to cover up the total lack of any real substance... just a little thing called good old-fashioned GAMEPLAY that seems to be forgotten nowadays... yep, I love all the super-duper powerups, and checkpoints.. yes recovery is HARD but not IMPOSSIBLE. You actually have to put in a little elbow grease to get your strength back! Something the little ones today could stand to learn from, if you ask me! They seem to want games where you can kill everything on the screen with one button press, right after inserting a coin! Instant gratification with no challenge. And personally, I usually prefer a "side-view" kind of shooter compared to a "bird's eye view" one, all those obstacles give levels a lot more personality, not such a common thing when every me-too game wants to look and play the same.

Me, I've been playing a lot of R-Type part two lately. I can only clear a couple of boards on my first man right now. I may wear out my joystick before I can manage my one quarter win! But I don't quit! What can I say, I prefer a little hard work to getting a free handout! Playing some Wings of Wor on my Sega too, and Biohazard Battle. Great vintage stuff!

>>9560230
this p much. zero mission doesn't replace or "improve" metroid 1 because they're drastically different in feel and presentation. they're both good and people saying there's no reason to play m1 when zero mission exists are fucking stupid
it's the same with m2 vs AM2R. they're just too different to say no one should ever play m2 again when _ exists.

by modern standards m2 does suck; too many identical tilesets and the metroid fights are missile spam shit. by 90s standards it was pretty dope. missile spam WAS metroid boss fights (and continued to be), there's a linear path forward so you don't get lost, but each area can be explored freely. other than the lack of color, it's a huge improvement over m1 with more detailed sprites and better controls. lack of a map doesn't matter as much as in m1.

AM2R "zero missions" the game as much as it can, with the modern powerups being forced in, weird gimmick mechanics in rooms, new rooms grafted into previously empty corners. metroid fights are better but still kinda shit, the AM2R bosses are kinda shit as well but they don't feel too out of place aside from the fucking super jetpack robot torizo.
overall it's really impressive for a fan project and i'd say worthy of being an official game if it had more nintendo polish on the gfx and sfx.

samus returns fucking sucked and i despise MercurySteam for the wretched experience and getting their hands on metroid 5. i so badly wish nintendo curated and protected the metroid franchise as carefully as they do with mario and zelda, but instead metroid gets passed around to every 3rd party studio that's interested, no matter how little they understand what made metroid enjoyable. yeah i mad

>people saying there's no reason to play m1 when zero mission exists are fucking stupid
I haven't played Zero Mission myself, but my guess is that people think M1 is "worse" because there's some grindy bullshit in the first game that later games fixed fairly quickly. For example, most Metroid games have that one enemy that's a pipe with bugs flying out of it in formation; when I played M1 I found that to be the most reliable way of replenishing health since stations that replenished all your health weren't a thing yet, so every instance of me doing a boss fight or exploring a new area was preceded by about ten minutes of me sitting in place shooting bugs until I harvested enough health to proceed. I beat this game for the first time by playing it on my friends' Switch at their house, they kept walking by and laughing at me sitting in place shooting bugs, asking me if I was having fun lol

By the way, every time I've seen people being told to avoid M1 it's always lorefags looking for an easier time. I think the list was ZM -> F -> SR -> SM, but I forgot where Fusion goes in that list so it's probably wrong.

>>9566110
The British economy was a little tight around then, so an increasingly inexpensive machine with super easy piracy had a lasting appeal. Many of the games are pretty dull or even shitty, but there's some pretty decent ones which are easy enough to find because they got pirated the most, even if the scene had a lot of shovelware (what popular system didn't though).
Famiclones and even bootleg Master Systems were a thing you'd see here and there in Britain in those days, so options did get better even on the cheap end, and even if the ZX Spectrum was a bit weak, the Commodore 64 was just as easy to pirate for but had much better games (the best stuff was NES and MS tier), so it was really popular, and probably the best value for your money in that market.

Its high art, the ultimate low IQ filter. It’s as rich and cultured a game I’ve ever encountered, incredible depth and variety. But it’s also merciless, if you don’t learn its mechanics fast you’ll be doomed before you’ve even started.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562387
>What makes this game so great?
No quest markers or fast travel (outside of catching rides between trade posts).
Not ruined by difficulty scaling like the rest of the series.
Actual good lore (and even better secret lore (and even better secret secret lore)).
Unique world building and aesthetics.
Wacky and exploitable gamesystems like spellcrafting that rewards creativity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9562387
I guess I'll try and explain the appeal of the game for me:
>true adventure, you are left to your own devices, no hand holding
>custom magic spells are really fun to experiment with
>its a rags to riches type of game, you start as a noob and gradually become more powerful
>you grow an intimate understanding of the land throughout the game as you are forced to learn landmarks, factions, travel methods, backstory, etc.
>the fast travel systems are all in universe, use silt striders, boats, mages guilds to travel between cities, use your own spells to create a custom waypoint
>there is actual unique loot to find in the world, its not level scaled random loot like the other elder scrolls
>main story is VERY interesting and compelling
>just the feel of completing even a simple quest is adventurous because you are navigating based on the journals directions and your knowledge of the land

It's true that you don't get much influence in how quests play out, since most of them are task oriented.
However, variance in your playthrough will depend on WHICH factions and characters you decide to do quests for.
Factions have base stat requirements and some are mutually exclusive with others (not all though).
On top of that the music, aesthetic, and worldbuilding are all A+ so it's just enjoyable to be in Vvardenfell.

My advice is to take it super slow, don't expect it to be a masterpiece in the first hour. Your character will be a low level piece of shit that can barely hit a target or run faster than a slug.
Remember you can hold attack to charge hits and don't fight with low stamina because it affects your hit chance.
If you give the game a chance you will fall in love with the world because of how intimately you are made to learn and interact with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Neat world with lots of places to find, lots to see and dig around in. Horrible combat and a plotline you need to put effort into giving a shit about. There's a billion items to find, but most of them don't really matter. You are given pretty much complete freedom to do whatever you want. Balance is kinda fucked, spells and skills range from worthless to entirely broken. Still pretty cool being able to fly around the world or run at Sanic speeds. Even at it's most patched and fixed, it's still buggy, glitchy, and very unstable. OpenMW doesn't exist because it's hard to run on modern OS'es, it exists to try and create a version of Morrowind that's actually stable and bug-free without trying to reverse engineer and fix every problem. The game came with the tool the devs themselves used to setup the game world and many features, allowing you to mod the game extensively. The game also supports these modifications natively as plug-ins, allowing you to turn them on and off from the main menu.
It's a mixed bag as a whole, but it has a lot going for it. It was also the first open-world fully-3D RPG on a console that I can think of. Computers had that years before Morrowind was released, but I can't think of any console RPGs that were fully-3D prior to the 6th generation, and open-world as well.

>>9562387
Just started playing it again via OpenMW. It's such an awesome little engine. No more load times or crashes. Can put hundreds of mods on with no issues if you get into modding.

Decent enough main quest. Detail rich world, A mechanic/skill system that is decently balanced and more like what true rpg gaming is about. (Wizards don't swing swords, and sword swingers don't cast magic) etc. You can do what your skill allows. So if you're shit with a bow; you'll miss A LOT until you purchase training in that skill. Very fun, in depth spellmaking system. Kino armor sets. A shit ton of hours of gameplay. The goty edition is really worth it for the dlc. etc. etc. It's a nerd game for nerds. Like, someone who plays dnd, in theory, should appreciate morrowind way more than skyrim.
